text:
- Your son's death
sparked a movement
called Black Lives Matter.

Do you think that you've
made progress Tracy?

TRACY: I think that there's
a small portion of progress

being made, but
overall, I don't I don't
think we've gone far enough.

Especially when we talk
about Black Lives Matter,

we talk about the contents of
I can't walk down the street,

or I can't walk away from
the police with my hands up,

I'm still getting
shot in the back.

Or I'm driving in my vehicle
and my hands on the dashboard,

and I still get killed
in front of my child,

or I get choked out on the
streets in front of a store.

So when we speak of
Black Lives Matter,

these are the lives being
taken away in those instances.

And no other nationalities being
taken away from us like that.

So we know that
all lives matter,

but it's Black Lives that are
being affected by the police

brutality, by the
just ration of all
the killings that's going on.

- When you see what happens
with police officers.

And the difference is when
people say crime happens

in the black community,
but police officers
are sworn to uphold justice.

They're supposed
to be the ones who

are keeping justice and
peace on the streets
and deescalating situations.

And in too many times, you
see that not happening.
